data.name: WinningReason_RegularQuoridorWin
data.value: Regular win (first on the other side)

data.name: WinningReason_ExceedanceOfMaxMoves
data.value: The maximum of allowed moves was exceeded

data.name: WinningReason_ExceedanceOfThoughtTime
data.value: The maximum thought time was exceeded

data.name: WD_LoosingMessage
data.value: Sry ... you got beaten by the bot

data.name: WD_SaveGameRequest
data.value: Do you want to save the Game?

data.name: QRP_GeneralParagraphText
data.value: Quoridor is an abstract strategy game for 2 or 4 Player. The OpenQuoridorFramework only considers the 2-player-game. Therefor only those rules are presented here.

data.name: QRP_GameSetupParagraphText
data.value: Quoridor is played on a board with 9 by 9 fields with spaces between these fields (picture 1). On the Board are two pawns, which are moved from field to field and there are 20 Walls that can be placed between the fields. On startup the pawns are placed on the fields e1 and e9 (see Quoridor-Notation). The player who controls the pawn on field e1 starts first.

data.name: QRP_GameGoalParagraphText
data.value: The game ends immediately when one pawn reaches on field of the most opposite row. This player wins.

data.name: QRP_GameFlowParagraphText
data.value: Both players move alternating until a winner is determined. When it is one player's turn, he have to choose between two different kinds of moves. Ether he has to move his pawn by one space or he has to place a wall on the board. If a player has no walls left, he has to move. The figure can only be moved by one space horizontal oder vertical, but not diagonal, not over a wall and not off the board. If the decides to place a wall, it is important to place this wall only between four fields, but not overlapping with another wall and not half off the board. It is also important that the opponend player always has a possible path to one of his goal-fields.

data.name: QRP_SpecialMoveParagraphText
data.value: If two pawns are in adjecent fields, so that one could step on the other (picture 2), this pawn can jump over the other pawn (picture 3). If the jumping pawn cannot reach the field behind the other pawn (because there is a wall or the end of the board), he can jump diagonal to the left or right of the pawn. Of course in this scenario the fields to jump on have to be reachable. The pictures 4 and 5 show two of these situations with the possible moves.

data.name: QNP_GeneralParagraphText
data.value: Because there is no offical Quoridor-notation, one for was created for the OpenQuoridorFramework. It is derived from several notations used across the quoridor-community.

data.name: QNP_TheBoardParagraphText
data.value: To address a field uniquely all rows are coded by the numbers 1 to 9 and all columns are coded by the letters 'a' to 'i' (picture 1). This results in a game-space of 81 fields from a1 in the lower left corner to i9 in the upper right corner.

data.name: QNP_FigureMoveParagraphText
data.value: A move, where the pawn is relocated is noted by the field he is stepping on. If, for example, a player moves from c3 to c4, this move is written down as 'c4'.

data.name: QNP_WallMoveParagraphText
data.value: When a wall is placed on the board this move gets notates by the unique position of this wall. A wall have to be placed between four field. Therefore it is sufficent to store one of these four fields. This notation uses the upper left field for this purpose. Additional the orientation has to be noted. If the wall is placed vertically this is denoted by an 'v'. Or an 'h' for horizontal placed walls.

data.name: QNP_ExampleParagraphText
data.value: In this notation the pawn on picture 2 are on 'c3' and 'e8'. The positions of the walls would be denoted as 'd4h' and 'f8v'.

data.name: HTWAB_GeneralProceedingItem1
data.value: 1. Create new solution with an empty project (of type ClassLibrary)

data.name: HTWAB_GeneralProceedingItem2
data.value: 2. Add OQF.Bot.Contracts.dll as reference to the project

data.name: HTWAB_GeneralProceedingItem3
data.value: 3. Create a bot-class and derive it from IQuoridorBot

data.name: HTWAB_GeneralProceedingItem5
data.value: 5. Start an test-application (e.g. PlayerVsBot) and test your bot

data.name: HTWAB_ImportantClassesParagraphNote
data.value: Note: All classes and structs are designed and implemented as immutables.

data.name: HTWAB_FieldCoordinateParagraphText
data.value: A FieldCoordinate defines a unique position on the board (see Quoridor-notation). The X- and Y-coordinate are implemented as enumerations.

data.name: HTWAB_PlayerAndStateParagraphText
data.value: The Player-class defines the invariant values of a player. These are the name of player and his starting position (PlayerType) on the board. The current status of a player is represented by the PlayerState-class. There you can find a reference to the player, the current position of the player on the board and number of wall the has left to spend.

data.name: HTWAB_WallParagraphText
data.value: The Wall-Class defines a wall on the board by its position and orientation (see Quoridor-notation). The position is FieldCoordinate and the orientation is defined by another enumeration.

data.name: HTWAB_BoardStateParagraphText
data.value: The current situation on the board is represented by the BoardState-class. All game-relevant informations are stored in it: all placed walls, the states of both players and the player who's turn it is. Additional to that can the complete game-history be reviewed by looking at LastBoardState and LastMove.

data.name: HTWAB_MovesParagraphText
data.value: Based on the abstract superclass Move, there are 3 different moves to choose from each turn. The FigureMove, to move the Pawn, the WallMove, to place a wall on the board, and the Capitulation, if you think there is no chance of winning any more.

data.name: HTWAB_GameConstraintsParagraphText
data.value: The GameConstraints-class contains the two restrictions for a bot for a game. One is the maximal timespan a bot can take to think about its next move. The other is the maximum of total moves each player can make in this game, before it is aborted.

data.name: HTWAB_GameFlowParagraphHeader
data.value: The bot's view of the Gameflow

data.name: HTWAB_GameFlowItem1
data.value: 1. The method Init(PlayerType, GameConstraints) is called. Thereby the bot is told on which side of the board he is starting and how the constraints for the upcomming game are.

data.name: HTWAB_GameFlowItem2
data.value: 2. Now the game is started. Every time when its the turn of the bot, the method DoMove(BoardState) is called. The argument tells how the current situation of the board is.

data.name: HTWAB_GameFlowItem3
data.value: 3. Now the bot has so much time, as the GameConstraints told him, to fire the NextMoveAvailable-Event to submit his next move.

data.name: HTWAB_GameFlowItem4
data.value: 4. Then it is the opponend players turn. When he has finished moving and it is your turn again, the DoMove(BoardState)-method is called again. This will be repeated until there is a winner.

data.name: HTWAB_GameFlowItem5
data.value: 5. A bot can always submit a debug-message to the UI by fireing the DebugMessageAvailable-Event.

data.name: HTWAB_ExampleParagraphText
data.value: The SimpleWalking bot is an examplary bot-implementation. You find it within the OpenQoridorFramework at 'OpenQuoridorFramework/Bots/SimpleWalkingBot/SimpleWalkingBot.cs' within the Git-repository (see About).

data.name: AP_SourceCodeSectionText
data.value: The sourceCode of the OpenQuoridorFramework can be found on gitHub

data.name: PvBH_Explanation01
data.value: 1. Browse for a bot-dll on the hard-drive and load it

data.name: PvBH_Explanation02
data.value: 2. Start a game (if a bot was loaded)

data.name: PvBH_Explanation03
data.value: 3. Start a game from progress-file (if a bot was loaded)

data.name: PvBH_Explanation04
data.value: 4. Name of the bot you are playing against

data.name: PvBH_Explanation08
data.value: 8. Save current game-progress to a text-file

data.name: PvBH_Explanation10
data.value: 10. The progress of the ongoing game

data.name: PvBH_Explanation11
data.value: 11. Number of walls, which the bot has left to spend

data.name: PvBH_Explanation12
data.value: 12. Save current debug-output to a text-file

data.name: PvBH_Note
data.value: Note: To submit a move just click on the board on the UI. You get a preview for wall-placement as well as for moving the pawn.

data.name: PvB_SaveGameProgressFileDialogTitle
data.value: Save Game Progress of currently ended game

data.name: PvB_ErrorMsg_NoDllPath
data.value: You have to choose a Bot-DLL before Starting a game

data.name: PvB_ErrorMsg_BotCanNotBeLoadedFromAsembly
data.value: Bot cannot be loaded as assembly

data.name: FVR_EmptyOrInvalidFile
data.value: The file is empty or invalid

data.name: FVR_FileContainsInvalidMove
data.value: The file contains an invalid move

data.name: FVR_FileContainsTerminatedGame
data.value: The file contains a game which already ended

data.name: PvB_ErrorMsg_ProgressFileCannotBeLoaded
data.value: The text-file connot be loaded as progress-file

data.name: HTWAB_HintParagraphText
data.value: You can simplify your debugging-process by modifying the properties of your bot-project in a way that the test-application PlayerVsBot is started automaticly with the bot loaded every time you start debugging. To do so (an example is shown in the picture above) you have to adjust the StartAction to launch the PlayerVsBot-application. In addition to that you have to add the result of the build-process (your bot-dll) as command-line-parameter for the test-application. Don't forget the quotation marks! There are three more possible CommandLine-Parameters. With "-disableBotTimeout" you can debug your bot as long as you want, without being interrupted by the bot's thinking-time-limit. And with "-disableClosingDialog" you can supress the dialogs which would be displayed if you close the program during a game. With '-progressFile="[...]"' you can start the game directly from an game-progress-file. This is helpful to debug a certain situation.

data.name: PvBH_Explanation20
data.value: 20. Resign from the game -> the bot wins

data.name: PvBH_Explanation21
data.value: 21. Number of walls, which you have left to spend

data.name: ClosingDialogMessage
data.value: Do you want exit during a ongoing game?

data.name: SavingDialogMessage
data.value: Do you want to save the current game progress?

data.name: FVR_FileContainsMoreMovesThanAllowed
data.value: The file contains more moves than allowed in the upcomming game
